name: makes
description: A DevSecOps framework powered by Nix.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#contents
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The project supports pre-releases or using old versions https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/releases
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Every release comes with a note, with the changes, fixed or updates on the project https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/releases
enhancement_responses_justification: Issues are always responded on creation if it was created by an external source outside the organization https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/issues
report_archive_justification: Issues are tracked publicly on the Github Issues tab https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The process explained here https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#code-contributions, vulnerabilities can be reported via issues
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Every issue is reviewed and labeled on creation https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/issues
build_justification: The process to build the project is explained here https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#at-a-glance
build_floss_tools_justification: The project was built using nix https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#getting-started
test_justification: One of the project goals is to build tools or test suites runnable on a CI/CD environment, so it uses its own tests https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#goal
test_most_justification: All tests are running using GitHub actions https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#configuring-on-github-actions
test_policy_justification: Every new feature is suggested to have tests and an automated job for workflows https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#code-contributions
warnings_justification: The project uses its own linter as an automated job on GitHub actions https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#code-contributions
warnings_fixed_justification: CI/CD pipeline fails if a job is not successful https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/actions
warnings_strict_justification: Pipelines fail if a test fails https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/actions
dynamic_analysis_justification: All releases are done by a PR on the GitHub repository, it executes all the jobs required.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project doesn't use memory-unsafe languages.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Workflows are defined, running on GitHub actions https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/tree/main/.github/workflows
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: Every command configured must run using the required options, or using default options to be functional.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: The installation process is explained here https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#getting-started
implementation_languages: Nix, Shell, Python, JavaScript, Ruby, HCL
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The project is a command-line/configuration product, so accessibility doesn't apply here.
internationalization_justification: The project is a command-line/configuration product, it doesn't generate any texts, except the command outputs.
sites_password_security_justification: The project is free/libre to download/install without any authentication.
maintenance_or_update_justification: All releases, including pre-releases and older ones, are stored here https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/releases
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: There haven't been any vulnerabilities reported in the last 12 months.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: All vulnerabilities are discussed as an issue https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#contributing-to-makes
coding_standards_justification: Every contribution to the project must go through CI/CD which evaluates syntax and code formats. https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#code-contributions
coding_standards_enforced_justification: The project uses its own tools to check coding styles https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes#format
build_standard_variables_justification: The projects' build process is using nix, so you can use any flags available for builds.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The projects' build process is using nix, so you can use any flags available for builds.
build_non_recursive_justification: Every build is isolated from the other ones. The project follows the Nix philosophy.
external_dependencies_justification: Every dependency is listed on the source code. Explicit and with pinned versions https://github.com/fluidattacks/makes/blob/main/flake.lock
dependency_monitoring_justification: External dependencies are updated commonly if needed.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Almost every feature on the project is independent of the other ones, in case some of the dependencies used are vulnerable they can be fixed easily.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Sonarcloud and Scorecard are used for this purpose.
regression_tests_added50_justification: Test cases were built using bugs as a reference.
implement_secure_design_justification: The purpose of the project is mostly to read arguments and write output, everything is isolated and not accessible on runtime.
input_validation_justification: Inputs are strictly typed so everything sent to the program is exactly what it needs.

name: microML
description: a library for numerical crunching and machine learning on microcontrollers
description_good_justification: Every single file and comment are in the English language, no jargon is utilized whatsoever.
interact_justification: Several clear and simple "md" files have been included in the repo, which provide such information.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
Several "md" files have been added to the repository for that purpose. Please, refer to the files "CONTRIBUTING.md", "RELEASES.md" and "SUPPORT.md" for more details. Please, find the URLs below:
https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/RELEASES.md
https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/SUPPORT.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: As this is still a very simple library, the instructions reported in the file "README.md" are essentially everything needed to get started. Moreover, the user is pointed towards the "test" directory which contains working and well commented examples.
documentation_interface_justification: For now, as this is a very basic release at the moment, all the information needed to understand the external interface is reported in the file "README.md". In that document the user is suggested to go to the "test" folder which include working and well documented examples.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: This is exactly the way we plan to proceed. There is no interim version at the moment since this is a brand new project.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: This is exactly the way we plan to proceed. There is no version numbering at the moment since this is a brand new project.
version_tags_justification: This is exactly the way we plan to proceed. We use GitHub for that purpose.
release_notes_justification: This is exactly the way we plan to proceed. There are no release notes at the moment since this is a brand new project.
release_notes_vulns_justification: No publicly vulnerabilities are known at the moment since this is a quite young project.
report_tracker_justification: We use the GitHub issue tracker.
report_process_justification: We do have a process to submit bug reports. It is documented in https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
report_responses_justification: This is how we plan to proceed. There are no bug reports for now because the repository is new.
enhancement_responses_justification: This is how we plan to proceed. We will always do our best to submit the majority of enhancement requests made by the community. We want to make sure that we follow the insights/suggestions of the whole community.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: We plan to be an open and transparent community. There are no info treated in this project which might be private since this is library about mathematics and machine learning.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: This is how we plan to proceed. We don't have any vulnerability report yet because the repository is new.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project utilizes only "gcc" and "avr-gcc" to be compiled. Both are FLOSS tools. No external dependencies are planed.
test_justification: Please, find the documentation at https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/README.md and https://github.com/microML/microML/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
test_invocation_justification: We provide a Makefile for that purpose.
test_most_justification: We plan to proceed in this way but there are no branches at the moment in the repository.
test_policy_justification: We provide information about the general policy in the files "CONTRIBUTING", "README" and "CODE_OF_CONDUCT". The main guiding principle is that a test suite must be in place so that the main branch of the repository is never compromised.
tests_are_added_justification: We do not have a complete test policy since the project is too young for that. Obviously, once the project becomes bigger there will be a test policy.
warnings_justification: The warning flags are included in the Makefile of the project.
know_secure_design_justification: We are a team of people who have experience in scientific and industrial software. Some of us are definitely qualified to design secure software. Some of us also have past experience with developing open/free software.
know_common_errors_justification: We are a team of people who have experience in scientific and industrial software. Please, see the previous comment.
delivery_mitm_justification: We plan to use GitHub for that purpose.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: This is exactly how we plan to proceed.
static_analysis_justification: We cannot apply such tools since the software produced in this library is intended for microcontrollers only.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Please, see previous comment. In any case, we plan to fix every vulnerability found as soon as possible.
static_analysis_often_justification: The code needs to be thoroughly analized at every commit since this code has to run on microcontrollers. No code that is not tested on actual hardware will be committed.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Please, comments above. This is a library for microcontrollers.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We plan to do this for sure but with different tools since this is a library for microcontrollers.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We use GitHub entirely for that purpose.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The repository does not and never will contain any information of that type.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: SPDX Golang Tools
description: Collection of Go packages to work with SPDX files
sites_https_justification: Code hosted on GitHub and documentation hosted at https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/spdx/tools-golang, both using HTTPS URLs.
description_good_justification: In the README.md file within the project, which displays when a visitor goes to the project website on GitHub.
interact_justification: Handled via Issues and Pull Requests within GitHub; information on some specifics (e.g. DCO usage, test coverage, etc.) available in CONTRIBUTING.md file.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The CONTRIBUTING.md file briefly indicates requirements for license choice / DCO usage and test coverage -- see https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: Described in README file and LICENSE.code file: https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/README.md; https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/LICENSE.code
floss_license_justification: The project's source code is dual-licensed, under a choice of either (1) Apache-2.0 OR (2) GPL-2.0 or any later version. The project's documentation is licensed under CC-BY-4.0.
floss_license_osi_justification: Apache-2.0 and GPL-2.0 are both OSI-approved, and the project's source code license gives the recipient the choice to use under either license.
documentation_basics_justification: Documentation available at https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/spdx/tools-golang, generated from in-code function comment documentation. The docs/ folder at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/tree/main/docs provides some additional details about assumptions and usage of the tools.
documentation_interface_justification: The documentation available at https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/spdx/tools-golang documents the major types and methods/functions that can be called.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All interim code releases are fully publicly visible on GitHub.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Using semantic versioning for each user-facing release, as required by Go for modules: https://go.dev/blog/publishing-go-modules
version_tags_justification: Tags visible at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/tags and GitHub releases visible at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/releases
release_notes_justification: Available at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/RELEASE-NOTES.md, beginning with 0.2.0 release; will be maintained for future releases.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Although we are not currently aware of any such vulnerabilities, there is not currently an explicit process in place to handle this, so I am marking it as 'Unmet' until such a process is established.
build_justification: The library is distributed as Golang source code, which any downstream user will rebuild themselves using their local Golang tools. The project does have an automated CI/CD test suite with broad coverage which runs automatically on each PR and commit.
build_common_tools_justification: Intended to be built using the standard Golang distribution.
build_floss_tools_justification: Intended to be built using the standard Golang distribution, which is available as open source: https://go.dev/LICENSE
test_justification: The test suite uses the Golang built-in testing functionality, which is part of the Golang FLOSS distribution. The tests themselves are incorporated into the SPDX Golang Tools codebase and are likewise FLOSS along with the rest of the distribution.
test_invocation_justification: Invoked using the standard 'go test' command.
test_most_justification: Code coverage is currently (at the time of last edit of this answer) 96%, as viewable at https://coveralls.io/github/spdx/tools-golang
test_policy_justification: Documented in the CONTRIBUTING file at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#test-coverage
tests_are_added_justification: Test coverage metrics are visible in https://coveralls.io/github/spdx/tools-golang, with sub-unit functionality coverage shown on that page. Major additional functionality in recent years has been the addition of rdfloader, jsonloader and jsonsaver, each of which has high test coverage visible on that page.
tests_documented_added_justification: Documented in the CONTRIBUTING file at https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#test-coverage
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Tests are automatically run, and build status + test coverage metrics are automatically updated, upon each commit or PR using GitHub Actions: https://github.com/spdx/tools-golang/actions
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Documentation in the code and at https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/spdx/tools-golang is in English, as are the issue and pull request discussions.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
maintained_justification: Currently maintained solely by original author, with significant contributions from GSoC participants and occasional contributions by other community members. Seeking to improve in the near term by bringing in multiple additional committers / maintainers.

name: eossr
description:
The ESCAPE OSSR library
The eOSSR Python library gathers all the developments made for the OSSR. In particular, it includes:
- an API to programmatically access the OSSR, retrieve records and publish content
- functions to map and crosswalk metadata between the CodeMeta schema adopted for the OSSR and Zenodo internal schema
- functions to help developers automatically contribute to the OSSR, in particular using their continuous integration (see also code snippets)

name: Shapeshifter
description:
Shapeshifter implements the Universal Smart Energy Framework for flexibility forecasting, offering, ordering, and settlement processes. Additionally, ShapeShifter enables trading via DSO/TSO coordination platforms that also support the protocol.

Shapeshifter enables a fast, fair, and low cost route to a smart energy future by delivering one common approach to efficiently connect smart energy projects and technologies. Its market structure, roles, rules and tools for the commoditization and trading of flexible energy usage work with existing and evolving energy markets.

Shapeshifter focuses specifically on the exchange of flexibility between aggregators (AGRs) and distribution system operators (DSOs) or between aggregators and transmission system operations (TSOs). It describes the corresponding market interactions between them to resolve grid constraints by applying congestion management or grid capacity management.

name: Ortelius
description: Ortelius is a unified microservice catalog that versions and tracks microservices, their consuming applications, ownership, blast radius and where they have been deployed with all critical deployment metadata. By centralizing and tracking detailed configuration data, Ortelius provides you a proactive view of how your microservice architecture is changing overtime. The latest version of Ortelius is maintained by the Ortelius Community managed by the Continuous Delivery Foundation (Linux Foundation). It was originally created by DeployHub and OpenMake Software. Our mission is to simplify the adoption of modern architecture through a world-class microservice management platform driven by a supportive and diverse global open source community.
contribution_justification: https://ortelius.io/contributor/
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://docs.ortelius.io/guides/contributorguide/how-to/
Opening an Issue
GitHub Issues are used to track all bugs, enhancement requests, and “todos.” Ortelius is spread across many repositories so the ortelius/ortelius repo is used for all issues. Issues should have a link, using markdown []() link format, to the true repository in which the bug, enhancement, or “todos” needs to be made.

Please be detailed in your description of the issue. Not everything needs to go in the summary line. Feel free to use the description area to provide additional details.

Making documentation changes
Documentation is stored in ortelius/ortelius-docs. The documentation is served up by a hugo/docsy server. You can run this server locally to view your changes before committing to Github.

The documentation is managed in two Guides - a User Guide and a Contributor Guide.

Setup for Documenation updates
Install hugo locally. If you are on Windows make sure to install the extended packages as well.
Fork the ortelius/ortelius-docs to your GitHub account.
Clone the new repo to your computer.
Launch an editor such as Visual Studio Code. Make sure the Markdown Preview Enhanced by Yiyi Wang is installed. This will give you a split screen of the markdown and the rendered version.
The markdown files can be found under the content/en/guides/contributorguide (this guide) and the content/en/guides/userguide (the end user guide).
Start your hugo server. Open a command prompt and cd to your local git repo directory. From the root of the repo run hugo server. This will start the local hugo server running. The pages can be viewed in your browser using the http://localhost:1313/guides url.
Next make a documentation change. This change will automatically be seen in the Visual Studio Code - Markdown Preview Enhanced window. Also, the hugo server will automatically render the changed markdown page.
Note: Visual Studio is only a preview and will not render all markdown updates such as embedded html. You will need to view the pages being hosted by the hugo server in your browser for an accurate rendering.

Markdown Cheat Sheet can be used for the basic page layout. CSS has been applied to the Docsy theme template in order to tweak the final page rendering.

Create a Pull Request to merge in your changes. See PR Cheat Sheet
Making coding changes
The Ortelius code base is stored across multiple repositories. Ortelius was originally written as a Java Servlet application running under Tomcat. The front end code is in Java Script using JQuery and JQuery Plugins. The backend code is Java that accesses the Postgres database via JDBC driver. The Ortelius Deployment Engine is written in C++. Plugins to CI tools are written in Python and Groovy.

New enhancements are being architected to follow the microservice implementation practices. These new microservices are written in Python or Golang and have their own separate repositories.

The goal is to move from the monolithic implementation, to hybrid and then to a pure microservice based implementation.

The Java backend code is easiest worked on using the Eclipse IDE, where as the other code can be handled with any editor such as Visual Studio Code.

A Postgres database needs to be installed for Ortelius to persist its data. Ortelius will create the necessary database tables on startup.

Steps
Fork the ortelius/ortelius to your GitHub account if you are working on the monolithic backend or frontend JS code, otherwise, for the Ortelius microservice repo.

Clone the new repo to your computer.

Make the coding changes with your favorite editor.

The monolithic code can be run and debug natively in Eclipse since a Tomcat Server using a connection to your local Postgres database.

The microservice code can be run and debugged natively in your editor. It will need to connect to the database over OBDC.

Create a Pull Request to merge in your changes. See PR Cheat Sheet

Creating Videos
Videos are hosted on the Ortelius Youtube Channel. Please contact one of the chairs to get access to upload to the channel.

Camtasia for Windows or HitFilm Express for OS/X can be used to edit the videos. Training videos should be edited to remove any stumbles or pauses.

Videos Requirements:

Must include the Ortelius Opening and Closing Clips.
Resolution of 1040p (1920 x 1080) when possible.
Added to appropriate YouTube playlist.
Project Management
Trello
Kanban Board for Ortelius is used to track tasks spanning multiple SIGs and development efforts. Trello cards will contain links to the GitHub issues where appropriate.

GitHub Triage Dashboard
Triage Dashboard #181 will be added in Q1 2021 to help with issue management.

GitHub Labels and Tags
GitHub issues will be label to help filter and navigate issues.

Release Numbering
Releases ending in ”.0” are major releases and this is where all new features land. Releases ending in another integer, like “0.X.1” and “0.X.2” are dot releases, and these are only going to contain bugfixes. Typically we don’t do dot releases for minor bugfixes (reserving these for larger items), but may occasionally decide to cut dot releases containing a large number of smaller fixes if it’s still a fairly long time before the next release comes out.
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.ortelius.io/guides/
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
